name: NPR
text: NPR’s Book Concierge has the largest batch of recommendations we’ve ever compiled – here are 380+ of our favorite 2020 titles. (And stick around to browse nearly 2,500 books from the last 8 years.) https://t.co/GTAiBdkhmg

name: NPR
text: Some parts of the U.S. are now grappling with a post-Thanksgiving surge of COVID-19 patients — while others dodged that fate. What lessons can we learn as we head into the Christmas season? https://t.co/vdEbC5aUuH

name: NPR
text: "It's classic Putin," says Konstantin Eggert, a Russian political commentator. "By not congratulating Biden for so long, he in his eyes at least proved that he's tough, he's strong, and, if need be, he's ready to take the fight all the way to Washington." https://t.co/EGgCDIGnHf

name: NPR
text: On the Warm Springs reservation in rural Oregon, work is underway to open an emergency housing site for people needing to isolate. Nearly 1 in 5 residents have tested positive for the coronavirus — and 14 have died from it. @OPB https://t.co/q1Zp2GFPre

name: NPR
text:
"My bank account has $4 in it right now. I would love the people in Washington who have decided not to give us more stimulus money to see what it's really like to live like this."
https://t.co/0pBE52S8dd

name: NPR
text:
RT @SachaPfeiffer: Remember the outrage over large companies getting Paycheck Protection Program money? The federal funding meant to help small businesses?

Many private charitable foundations also got PPP.

Some are linked to the families of Warren Buffett and Walt Disney: https://t.co/DJZ29gXqGW

name: NPR
text:
BREAKING: The House has approved a $900 billion coronavirus relief bill, after months of partisan sniping over what elements should be included in the measure. It heads to the Senate next.
https://t.co/WnVMnGIVtr

name: NPR
text: RT @NPR: In the 4-block radius where George Floyd was killed, residents and volunteers work to keep things running at the makeshift memorial. Here’s how one caretaker describes his mission to present what he calls an “aesthetic dignity” to the space. @MPRnews https://t.co/eaUjhFqH7c

name: NPR
text:
Here's the latest on the SolarWinds hack — including what investigators are doing now and how targeted agencies and companies are responding.
https://t.co/grj5xEhmQB

name: NPR
text:
Nearly 8 million people have fallen into poverty since the middle of the year, according to new data. Researchers attribute that sharp increase to the expiration of federal aid programs.
https://t.co/VcyPMdBmlL

name: NPR
text:
The Vatican says it's "morally acceptable" to get a COVID-19 vaccine, even if its research or production involved using cell lines derived from aborted fetuses, due to the "grave danger" of the pandemic.
https://t.co/noaUEJHs3z

name: NPR
text: A leader of the Proud Boys says he burned the Black Lives Matter banner at a D.C. church during a recent pro-Trump rally. Local police are investigating the incident as a hate crime. @DCist https://t.co/ooaRlRYfgB

name: NPR
text: The federal government has released an updated set of detailed hospital-level data showing the toll COVID-19 is taking on health care facilities, including how many inpatient and ICU beds are available on a weekly basis. https://t.co/JoO33e5mf4

name: NPR
text: Christopher Krebs, the former top cybersecurity official in the U.S., says Russia is to blame for a massive breach that's affected the State Dept., Pentagon, Treasury Dept. and Homeland Security. https://t.co/jVIqzjvt3u

name: NPR
text:
More than 70 West Point cadets have been accused of cheating on a calculus final exam in May after they all made the same errors on the test. It's the worst academic scandal since 1976, instructors say.
https://t.co/pOgRS6imp7

name: NPR
text:
Border Patrol plans to build 30-foot fences at Friendship Park, drastically altering the park's landscape on the U.S-Mexico border, which has tied the binational community together for years. @KPBSnews
https://t.co/8EWAGSQsRP

name: NPR
text:
New Zealand says it will provide free doses of coronavirus vaccines to its residents as well as neighboring nations Tokelau, Cook Islands, Niue, Samoa, Tonga, and Tuvalu, should they want them.
https://t.co/suF9Y16BMd

name: NPR
text: Mourning and celebrating. Coping and distancing. 2020 has been a year of collective emotional dissonance. Here are the stories that hit home in 2020. https://t.co/kRjqrM36u9

name: NPR
text: NPR’s Book Concierge has the largest batch of recommendations we’ve ever compiled – here are 380+ of our favorite 2020 titles. (And stick around to browse nearly 2,500 books from the last 8 years.) https://t.co/pB7fTkA9Mc

name: NPR
text: The Trump administration has trimmed its lame-duck sell-off of oil rights in the Alaska National Wildlife Refuge, taking some 30% of the acreage off the table. The U.S. Geological Survey says the removed land has negligible potential for oil. @alaskapublic https://t.co/bVLrSuQGyy

name: NPR
text: Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny says he has uncovered details of his own poisoning by duping one of the Kremlin agents involved into revealing how it was done. https://t.co/jjjTbqHY8L

name: NPR
text:
A 2015 study by the Bureau of Labor Statistics found that the law was the least racially diverse profession in the country.

Due to expensive cost, lack of mentorship, and admission deadlines, applying to law becomes a difficult task. https://t.co/WBp6hn8EeX

name: NPR
text: 2021 will be a test regarding thousands of state legislators who plan to meet safely during a pandemic. This will be critical considering that there have already been some deaths among legislators along with more than 150 infections according to one tally. https://t.co/UoQRzr5xOO

name: NPR
text: RT @Lucian_Kim: The Kremlin expects Biden to talk about human rights. But if he were to invite, say @navalny, to the White House, Putin would see that as a very unfriendly act, says @kvoneggert. My preview of US-Russian relations after Trump: https://t.co/65pQtoqnhi

name: NPR
text: In Hawaii, the state government has used some of the assistance funds to bring back an idea for creating jobs from the era of the Great Depression. https://t.co/AW94qBcI8m

name: NPR
text: Late Sunday, Congress passed a bill to allay some of those fears involving unexpected medical bills. The measure is included in a nearly 5,600-page package providing coronavirus economic relief and government funding for the rest of the fiscal year. https://t.co/RWWkhRV8UQ

name: NPR
text: Fifty years ago, a simple but tragic love story became a global sensation. Love Story, the romantic tearjerker, broke box office records and the book it was based on was a bestseller that was translated into more than 30 languages. https://t.co/0CmTUsFVvU

name: NPR
text: RT @Laur_npr: When @JolieMyers and I started working on this series about loss during the pandemic, I didn't know where to start. When I interviewed people about what they lost, so many of them took a deep breath and started with "I mean...everything, really."When @JolieMyers and I started working on this series about loss during the pandemic, I didn't know where to start.… https://t.co/Ts2n7FoA7I

name: NPR
text: Black members of the U.S. Air Force are treated differently than their white counterparts in a wide range of areas, including promotions and military justice, a new internal investigation reveals. https://t.co/pSaLPxWquR

name: NPR
text: BREAKING: President-elect Joe Biden plans to nominate Miguel Cardona, the head of Connecticut's public schools, to be his secretary of education, a source familiar with the decision tells NPR's Juana Summers. https://t.co/dos1o5p36s

name: NPR
text: Join Morning Edition and Up First hosts David Greene and Rachel Martin, plus trivia mastermind Terri Simon, for three rounds of friendly, competitive holiday trivia. https://t.co/DCzRrXHMtM https://t.co/gUjiO3NHwI

name: NPR
text: Cyberpunk 2077 was supposed to be the biggest game of the year. A decade in development, years of hype, a breathless final run-up to launch day, launch hour and launch minute, this was it. The One. But the game is a buggy mess. https://t.co/TNT0feTsTQ

name: NPR
text: "We're still beating back disinformation and claims of technical manipulation that just simply aren't true," says Matthew Masterson, a top deputy to Christopher Krebs at the Department of Homeland Security. https://t.co/0nPYJ6uy7l

name: NPR
text:
RT @1a: The holidays will likely be different this year. 

But @inagarten says it's even more important to celebrate now so that life has some tradition and normalcy.

https://t.co/gQrtnASnQF

name: NPR
text:
California Gov. Gavin Newsom has selected Secretary of State Alex Padilla to replace Vice President-elect Kamala Harris in the U.S. Senate.

Padilla, 47, the son of Mexican immigrants, will be the first Latino from the state to hold the position. https://t.co/iAwEKGRlxH

name: NPR
text: Due to South Korea's third wave of coronavirus infections, the country will tightened nationwide restrictions. Beginning on Christmas Eve, South Koreans cannot eat out in groups larger than four. Skiing and skating venues will be closed.  https://t.co/pjHDRAj4hM

name: NPR
text: RT @witfnews: Roughly 35,000 students came back to Penn State this fall for classes during the coronavirus pandemic. One out of every seven of those students contracted COVID-19 during the semester. https://t.co/Sxc64K62cz @WPSU

name: NPR
text:
The creation of new Smithsonian museums dedicated to Latinos and women can now move forward. 

"Victory finally came today," Sen. Bob Menendez (D-NJ) wrote in a statement. Noting that a National Museum of the American Latino has been decades in the making. https://t.co/Td20WmmLBs

name: NPR
text: There are fewer than ten days left to make your year-end donation to support NPR and public radio. Invest in another year of reliable reporting and insightful analysis by giving today. https://t.co/LzgHFrLiTo https://t.co/gUOz3JLr0E

name: NPR
text: The head of the German pharmaceutical company BioNTech expressed confidence that his company's vaccine would be effective against a coronavirus variant rapidly infecting people across London and southern England. https://t.co/LSZjcv3x1z

name: NPR
text: South Carolina Gov. Henry McMaster has tested positive for the coronavirus and is experiencing "mild symptoms," according to a statement from his office. https://t.co/vun8f1TQsD

name: NPR
text:
Stargazers around the world didn't pass up an opportunity to see a rare event in the night sky.

On Monday evening, Jupiter and Saturn appeared closer to each other than they have for hundreds of years, in what has become known as the "Great Conjunction." https://t.co/oJ7LWy3MTF

name: NPR
text:
Jaromy Floriano Navarro thought she was getting an operation to remove a cyst on her ovary until the driver who brought her to the hospital said otherwise. 

"She was just like, you know you're having a hysterectomy, right?" said the driver to Floriano. https://t.co/UgcFCdcJkD

name: NPR
text: Nearly 8 million people have fallen into poverty since the middle of the year, according to new data. Researchers attribute that sharp increase to the expiration of federal aid programs. https://t.co/6VxJ3VLfg1
